{{About|the form of assault}} {{pp-move-indef}}
"'''Knockout game'''" is one of the names given in the United States by news media and others to assaults in which one person (with others acting as accomplices or lookouts) attempt to "knock out", with a single [[sucker punch]], an unsuspecting victim. The assaults have similarities to the [[happy slapping]] trend seen in Europe, in which [[camera phone]]s are used to record assaults. Other names given to assaults of this type include "'''knockout'''", "'''knockout king'''", "'''point 'em out, knock 'em out'''", and "'''polar-bearing'''" or "'''polar-bear hunting'''" (allegedly called such when the victim is white and the assailants are not).<ref name=nbcpolar/><ref name=nypostpolar /><ref name=cbspolar/>
Serious injuries and even deaths have been attributed to the knockout game. Some news sources report that there was an escalation of such attacks in late 2013, and, in some cases, the attacker was charged with a [[hate crime]].<ref name=nbcpolar/><ref name="DN CH"/><ref name=jweek1/> Other media analysts, such as Slate, have cast doubt on the reportedly widespread nature of the game and have labeled the trend, although not the attacks themselves, a [[Urban legend|myth]].<ref name=slate>{{cite web|last=Roller|first=Emma|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/weigel/2013/11/25/why_the_knockout_game_trend_is_a_myth.html|title=Why the 'Knockout Game' trend is a myth|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|date=November 25, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Melanie|last=Eversley|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/11/26/knockout-game-myth/3729635|title=Reports: Alleged Trend of 'knockout game' a myth|work=[[USA Today]]|date=November 26, 2013}}</ref><ref name=times/><ref name=beast/>
==History of attacks== ===1992–2009=== {{see also|Murder of Yngve Raustein|Happy slapping}} In September 1992, Norwegian exchange student [[Murder of Yngve Raustein|Yngve Raustein]] was killed by three teenagers who—according to [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], prosecutors—were playing a game called "knockout." Local teens said that the object is to render an unsuspecting target unconscious with a single punch, and, if the assailant does not succeed, his companions will turn on him instead.<ref name=yngve>{{cite news|title=MIT student's death attributed to violent "knockout" game|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2pZGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lvgMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6167,4733376&dq=violent+knockout+game&hl=en|accessdate=February 11, 2016|newspaper=[[The Day (New London)|The Day]]|date=1992-09-23}}</ref>
In 2005 in the United Kingdom, [[BBC News]] reported on the [[happy slapping]] incidents, in which the attacks were filmed for the purpose of posting online.<ref name=DoesHappy>{{cite news|last=Akwagyiram|first=Alexis|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/4539913.stm |title=UK | Does 'happy slapping' exist?|publisher=BBC News|date=2005-05-12|accessdate=}}</ref> The French government responded to this trend by making it illegal to film any acts of violence and post them online, with a spokesperson for then President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] saying that the law was indeed directed at "happy slapping."<ref name=FrenchSlap>{{cite news|last=Kannampilly|first=Ammu|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/story?id=2936331 |title=French Slap Back at 'Happy Slappers'|publisher=ABC News|date=March 8, 2007}}</ref>
Three teens were arrested in [[Decatur, Illinois]], in September 2009, and charged in the killing of a bicyclist, 61, who was stomped to death, and the attempted murder of another man, 46, who was also attacked and stomped. It was claimed that the teens were playing "point 'em out, knock 'em out," where a person is selected and a group of attackers attempts to render the victim unconscious.<ref name=TeensArraigned>{{cite news|first=Ron|last=Ingram|url=http://herald-review.com/news/local/article_88214bad-f545-503b-8d8a-ecfa2b4dae29.html|title=Teens arraigned for Decatur murder|work=[[Herald & Review]]|date=September 21, 2009}}</ref><ref name=chicago/>
In June 2009, a 29-year-old man was beaten in a [[Columbia, Missouri]], parking garage by a group of teens who told police that they were playing a game called "knockout king," where they would find an unsuspecting person and attempt to knock him out with a single punch.<ref name=ViolenceFor/>
===2011–2013=== In April 2011, Hoang Nguyen, 72, died in [[St. Louis, Missouri]], after he was attacked in what was described by a local [[CBS]] station as "part of the so-called knockout game". Nguyen's wife, Yen, 62, was injured. After the trial, the assailant, Elex Murphy, a teenager who was 18 at the time of the assault, was sentenced to life in prison plus 25 years.<ref name=ViolenceFor>{{cite news|first1=Jennifer|last1=Mann|first2=Marlon A.|last2=Walker|title=Violence for fun may be spreading among teens|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/crime-and-courts/article_a234c676-46b7-5c66-a193-dd09fc49d8b8.html|newspaper=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]|date=April 22, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://stlouis.cbslocal.com/2013/05/02/elex-murphy-gets-life-plus-25-years-for-knockout-game-murder|title=Elex Murphy Gets Life Plus 25 Years for Knockout Game Murder|publisher=[[KMOV]]|date=2013-05-02|accessdate=2013-12-09}}</ref><ref name=king>{{cite news|first=Chad|last=Garrison|date=2011-04-21|title=Elex Murphy: St. Louis Teen Allegedly Killed Elderly Immigrant As Part Of Game|url=http://blogs.riverfronttimes.com/dailyrft/2011/04/elex_murphy_murder_hoang_nguyen_st_louis_immigrant_vietnam.php|newspaper=Riverfront Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first1=Jennifer|last1=Mann|date=2013-05-03|title='Knockout game' widow tells of lonely life after husband's murder|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/crime-and-courts/knockout-game-widow-tells-of-lonely-life-after-husband-s/article_636cb831-f292-5238-b70d-5e523205ff1f.html|newspaper=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|accessdate=January 10, 2016}}</ref>
In July 2012, 62-year-old Delfino Mora was attacked by three teens and killed in West [[Rogers Park, Chicago]]. Anthony Malcolm, who recorded the attack on his cell phone and publicized it, was sentenced to 30 years in prison. Two other teens were awaiting trial in September 2013. The attack was said to be part of a game called "pick 'em out, knock 'em out."<ref name=chicago>{{cite web|last=Moser|first=Whet|url=http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/The-312/July-2012/Point-Em-Out-Knock-Em-Out-Knockout-King-Happy-Slapping-and-Random-Street-Violence|title='Point Em Out Knock Em Out,' 'Knockout King', 'Happy Slapping', and the Murder of Delfino Mora|publisher=Chicagomag.com|date=2012-07-18|accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.suntimes.com/22522995-761/30-year-sentence-for-teen-in-videotaped-beating-death-of-delfino-mora.html|title=30-year sentence for teen in taped beating death of Delfino Mora|publisher=Suntimes.com|date=2013-09-12|accessdate=2013-12-09}}</ref>
In 2013, a series of these attacks resulted in the deaths of the victims, all with some sort of game as a precipitating factor. Michael Daniels, 51, of [[Syracuse, New York]] died a day after being attacked in May 2013, with the "knockout game" later mentioned in regard to his death.<ref>{{cite news|date=2013-05-30|title=A punch from nowhere, and Michael Daniels' rough life ends in a senseless beating|url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2013/05/michael_daniels_rough_life_end.html|agency=Syracuse.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/attacks-around-us-probed-knockout-game-215216013.html|title=Attacks around US probed for link to Knockout Game|agency=Associated Press|date=2013-11-21|accessdate=January 10, 2016}}</ref>
Ralph Santiago, a disabled homeless resident of [[Hoboken, New Jersey]], was found dead after being attacked by three boys whose assault was linked to the "knockout" game.<ref>{{cite news|date=2013-09-23|title=Hoboken neighbors reeling after arrest of three young teens in murder of a disabled man|url=http://www.nj.com/jjournal-news/index.ssf/2013/09/hoboken_neighbors_still_reelin.html|agency=NJ.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=2013-11-21|title=New Jersey Homeless Man Ralph Santiago, Killed By Teens As Part of Horrific 'Knockout' Game|url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2013/11/21/knockout-game-new-horrific-youth-sport-that-nothing-short-deadly|agency=Fox News Latino}}</ref>
''[[Yale Daily News]]'' reported seven attacks during November 2013 in [[New Haven, Connecticut]] that could be associated with the knockout game. [[Yale University]]'s chief of police wrote an email to the campus community pertaining to the issue on November 21.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2013/12/05/police-respond-to-knockout-threat|title=Police respond to knockout threat|publisher=Yale Daily News|date=2013-12-05|accessdate=2013-12-08}}</ref>
In the United States, ''[[The New York Times]]'' noted "a growing log of reports of such crimes in the Northeast and beyond".<ref name=times/> A number of news stories in late November 2013 covered incidents in [[Crown Heights, Brooklyn]], where a series of attacks took place during October and November of that year.<ref name="DN CH">{{cite news|first=Thomas|last=Tracy|date=November 12, 2013|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/alleged-assaults-rock-crown-heights-article-1.1514604|title=NYPD investigating Crown Heights 'knockout' attacks on Jews as possible hate crimes|work=New York Daily News}}</ref><ref name="jweek1">{{cite web|first=Jonathan|last=Mark|url=http://www.thejewishweek.com/news/new-york-news/knockout-attacks-concern-crown-heights|title='Knockout' Attacks A Concern|publisher=The Jewish Week|date=2013-11-20|accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref><ref name="chinfo-11-12-13">{{cite web|url=http://crownheights.info/crime/410708/media-coverage-cbs-abc-report-on-knockout-jews-assaults|title=Media Coverage: CBS, ABC, NBC and Daily News Report on 'Knockout' Assaults|publisher=Crownheights.info|date=2013-11-12|accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref><ref name="DNA">{{cite web|first=Sonja|last=Sharp|date=November 25, 2013|url=http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20131125/crown-heights/brooklyn-jewish-leaders-offer-1500-reward-for-knockout-game-arrests|title=Brooklyn Jewish Leaders Offer $1,500 Reward for 'Knockout Game' Arrests|publisher=DNAinfo|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131126054253/http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20131125/crown-heights/brooklyn-jewish-leaders-offer-1500-reward-for-knockout-game-arrests|archivedate=November 26, 2013|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Yori|last=Yanover|url=http://www.jewishpress.com/news/breaking-news/crown-heights-knockout-the-jew-attacks-serial-hate-crimes/2013/11/14|title=Crown Heights 'Knockout the Jew' Attacks Serial Hate Crimes|publisher=The Jewish Press|date=November 14, 2013}}</ref> As a result, the [[New York City Police Department|NYPD]] responded by stepping up patrols in certain neighborhoods.<ref>{{cite news|first1=Liz|last1=Fields|first2=Gillian|last2=Mohney|date=November 24, 2013 |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/knockout-game-suspect-charged-hate-crime/story?id=20992590|title='Knockout Game' Suspect Charged With Hate Crime|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=January 10, 2016}}</ref>
On November 24, 2013, in [[Katy, Texas]], an 81-year-old African-American man was attacked and hospitalized. Two weeks later, Conrad Alvin Barrett, 29, was arrested after allegedly showing an off-duty police officer a video he recorded with his cell phone of himself perpetrating the attack and explicitly referencing "knockout". Investigators revealed that there were other videos on his phone in which he used racial epithets and another in which he wondered if he would receive media attention if he were to commit a "knockout game" attack on a black man. This was one of the first cases in which the victim was African-American. Previous instances in the US primarily involved white or Asian victims and African-American assailants. The [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] subsequently charged Barrett with a hate crime, the only time the DOJ involved itself in prosecuting these attacks. Barrett's attorney claimed his client suffers from [[bipolar disorder]] and was not on medication at the time of the attack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.khou.com/story/news/2014/07/24/12294464|title=Katy Man Charged With Hate Crime For Breaking Jaw Of Elderly Man In 'Knockout Game' Attack|publisher=[[KHOU]]|date=December 26, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abclocal.go.com/ktrk/story?section=news/local&id=9372582|title=Katy Man Charged With Hate Crime For Breaking Jaw Of Elderly Man In 'Knockout Game' Attack|publisher=Abclocal.go.com|date=2013-12-27|accessdate=2014-01-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/texas-man-charged-with-hate-crime-after-knockout-attack|title=Texas Man Charged With Hate Crime After 'Knockout' Attack|publisher=CBS News|date=December 27, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first1=Jocelyn|last1=Lane|first2=Chelsea J.|last2=Carter|date=December 28, 2013|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/12/27/justice/texas-knockout-charge|title=FBI Agent Quotes Texas Man Bragging About 'Knockout, Baby!'|publisher=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/12/27/22074834-texan-charged-with-hate-crime-for-knockout-game-hit-denied-bail?lite|title=Texan Charged With Hate Crime For 'Knockout Game' Hit Denied Bail|publisher=Usnews.nbcnews.com|date=2013-12-27|accessdate=2014-01-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Stephen|last=Dinan|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/dec/26/federal-authorities-charge-white-knockout-suspect-|title=Federal Authorities Charge White 'Knockout' Suspect With Hate Crime|work=The Washington Times|date=December 26, 2013}}</ref> In October 2015, Barrett was sentenced to 71 months (5 years and 11 months) in federal incarceration. He still faces charges in state court.<ref name="George_chron1">{{cite web|url=http://www.houstonchronicle.com/neighborhood/katy/crime-courts/article/Defendant-in-hate-crime-sentenced-to-71-months-in-6575137.php|title=Defendant In Hate Crime Sentenced To 71 Months In Prison|last=George|first=Cindy|date=October 16, 2015|publisher=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=December 1, 2015}}</ref>
===2013–2017=== On July 27, 2016 in [[Milan]], Italian police arrested a young Spaniard on vacation in Italy, after he made repeated assaults on passersby, similar to this "game".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://internacional.elpais.com/internacional/2016/07/28/actualidad/1469716920_604398.html|title=Detenido en Milán un joven español que golpeaba sin motivo a los transeúntes|date=July 27, 2016}}</ref> On that same date, in [[Greenville, South Carolina]] a man was attacked while playing ''[[Pokemon GO]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenvilleonline.com/story/news/crime/2016/07/29/police-investigate-attempted-murder-peace-center-plaza/87756626/?kwp_0=193178&kwp_4=759897&kwp_1=382121|title=Police investigate attempted murder at Peace Center Plaza|website=Greenvilleonline.com|date=2016-07-30|accessdate=2016-08-21}}</ref>
In December 2015 a man in New York was reported assaulted by a non-black teen playing the "knockout game". The perpetrator turned himself in two months later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abc7ny.com/news/paterson-teen-allegedly-involved-in-knockout-game-facebook-video-turns-himself-in-/1190091|title=Teen allegedly involved in knockout game on Facebook video turns himself in|accessdate=August 20, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abc7ny.com/news/paterson-teen-pleads-guilty-in-knockout-game-punch-attack/1492487/|title=Paterson teen pleads guilty in 'knockout game' punch seen on Facebook|accessdate=July 22, 2017}}</ref>
On August 29, 2016 a 30-year-old [[Guatemala]]n, Mardoquo Sincal Jochola, was fatally assaulted in Philadelphia and is alleged to have been a victim of the "knockout game".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2016/08/29/victim-of-lawncrest-attack-dies-from-injuries|title=Police Consider ‘Knockout Game’ A Possibility In Fatal Lawncrest Attack|accessdate=August 29, 2016}}</ref>
On July 31, 2017, an unidentified man was caught on camera while knocking out a 24-year-old woman, Yana Rozanova, in [[Pervomaisk, Mykolaiv Oblast]], Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|title=На Украине прохожий, ударив девушку по лицу, отправил ее в нокаут (ВИДЕО)|url=http://www.newsru.com/crime/09aug2017/knockout24ywomukr.html|publisher=[[NEWSru]]|date=August 9, 2017|accessdate=August 9, 2017|language=ru}}</ref>
==Racial components== ===Antisemitism=== Several attacks on [[Jewish American|Jewish]] victims in [[Brooklyn]] in 2013 have been called [[antisemitism|antisemitic]] hate crimes.<ref name=nbcpolar>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Knockout-Game-Polar-Bearing-Hate-Crimes-Punch-Slap-Video-232695381.html|title=Police Added in Brooklyn Neighborhood Amid "Knockout Game" Attacks|publisher=[[WNBC]]|date=2013-11-20|accessdate=2013-11-23}}</ref><ref name=nypostpolar>{{cite news|last=Gartland|first=Michael|url=https://nypost.com/2013/11/23/i-was-in-shock-they-were-all-laughing-knockout-game-victim-speaks-out|title=I Was A Victim Of The Knockout Game|publisher=Nypost.com|date=2013-11-23|accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref><ref name=cbspolar>{{cite web|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2013/11/23/4-held-in-latest-alleged-knockout-game-attack-in-brooklyn|title=Man Charged In Latest Alleged ‘Knockout Game’ Attack In Brooklyn|publisher=[[WCBS-TV]]|date=2013-11-23|accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Velez|first=Natasha|url=https://nypost.com/2013/11/22/nypd-hate-crime-unit-probing-brooklyn-knockout-attack|title=Jewish Man Clocked In 'Knockout' Attack|publisher=[[New York Post]]|date=2013-11-22|accessdate=2013-11-23}}</ref> ''[[ABC Nightline]]'' reported that New York City police believed that antisemitism was likely to be a motive in the attacks, as all eight victims were identified as Jewish.<ref name=nightline>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Nightline/video/sucker-punch-spike-knockout-game-attacks-21013587|title=Sucker Punch: Possible Spike in 'Knockout Game' Attacks|publisher=[[ABC Nightline]]|date=2013-11-26|accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref>
Jewish community leaders in Brooklyn have spoken out on the subject,<ref name="DNA"/><ref name=Cnn1>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/11/22/justice/knockout-game-teen-assaults|title=Police keep close eye on 'knockout' game|publisher=Cnn.com|accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref> and the [[Anti-Defamation League]] regional office issued a public statement on knockout attacks "targeting Jewish individuals in Brooklyn".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newyork.adl.org/news/adl-statement-on-knockout-attacks-in-brooklyn|title=ADL statement|publisher=Newyork.adl.org|date=2013-11-21|accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref> Amrit Marajh, a 28-year-old suspect in an attack that took place in Brooklyn, was charged with a hate crime as his victim was Jewish.<ref name=nbcpolar/><ref name=jweek1/><ref>{{cite web|url =https://news.yahoo.com/knockout-game-suspect-charged-hate-crime-100039465--abc-news-topstories.html|title='Knockout Game' Suspect Charged With Hate Crime|last1=Fields|first1=Liz|last2=Mahoney|first2=Gillian|date=November 24, 2013|website=Yahoo.com|accessdate=November 24, 2013}}</ref> Marajh has claimed innocence and denied the claims of antisemitism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latinopost.com/articles/1340/20131125/knockout-attack-suspect-charged-with-hate-crime-says-hes-not-anti-semitic.htm|title='Knockout' Attack Suspect Charged With Hate Crime Says He's Not Anti-Semitic|publisher=Latino Post|date=2013-11-17|accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref>
On December 3, newly elected [[African-American]] [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] New York City councilwoman [[Laurie Cumbo]] added a letter to her Facebook page saying: "The accomplishments of the Jewish community triggers feelings of resentment, and a sense that Jewish success is not also their success." The Anti-Defamation League said her post was "troubling" and that it evoked "classic anti-Semitic stereotypes."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/brooklyn/councilwoman-black-jewish-resentment-talk-slammed-article-1.1538099|title=NYC councilwoman's talk of black-Jewish resentment, 'knockouts' called racist|publisher=NY Daily News|date=2013-10-21|accessdate=2013-12-08|location=New York}}</ref> Cumbo later issued an apology for the remarks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://collive.com/show_news.rtx?id=28096&alias=cumbo-regrets-her-knockout|title=Cumbo Regrets Her Knockout|publisher=Collive.com|date=2013-12-10|accessdate=2013-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://crownheights.info/crown-heights-news/416795/councilwoman-apologizes-for-insensitive-comments|title=Councilwoman Apologizes for Insensitive Comments|publisher=Crownheights.info|date=2013-12-10|accessdate=2013-12-11}}</ref> Cumbo added that the lives of victims and suspects will never be the same and that attackers would be "prosecuted to the full extent of the law".<ref name="hamodia"/> NYPD Commissioner [[Raymond Kelly]] later stated that he was avoiding referring to the attacks as part of any sort of trend to avoid further copycat attacks and has instead been labeling them as hate crimes.<ref name=msnphilly/>
==Response== ===Government action=== ===New York=== On November 21, 2013<ref name="cbslocal1">{{cite web|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2013/11/21/new-york-lawmaker-targets-knockout-game-with-new-bill|title=New York Lawmaker Targets 'Knockout Game' With New Bill|publisher=Newyork.cbslocal.com|date=2013-11-21|accessdate=2013-12-08}}</ref> [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[New York State Assembly|New York State assemblyman]] [[Jim Tedisco]] put forward legislation called the "Knockout Assault Deterrent Act"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/11/22/justice/knockout-game-teen-assaults|title=Police keep close eye on reports of disturbing 'knockout' game|publisher=CNN.com|accessdate=2013-12-08}}</ref> to charge [[juvenile offender]]s in these type of attacks as adults, and would also punish those who were found recording the attacks.<ref name="cbslocal1"/><ref name=cnn/> [[New York State Senate|New York State Senator]] [[Hugh Farley]] (also a Republican) supports legislation that would make assailants linked to the knockout game liable to harsher sentences, would try juvenile offenders as adults, and would make accomplices criminally responsible.<ref name=cnn/><ref name=wynt>{{cite web|url=http://wnyt.com/article/stories/s3228303.shtml|title=Bill would crack down on "Knockout Game" assaults|publisher=WNYT.com|date=2013-11-25|accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref> Democratic assemblyman John McDonald, while admitting stiffer penalties were warranted claimed Tedisco's bill was unnecessary.<ref name=wynt/>
===Wisconsin=== In [[Wisconsin]], Republican State Assemblyman [[Dean Kaufert]] said he was considering drafting a bill to deter attacks.<!--any results?--><ref>{{cite web|author=The Associated Press|url=http://www.twincities.com/news/ci_24612688/kaufert-considers-bill-targeting-knockout-game|title=Kaufert considers bill targeting 'knockout game'|publisher=TwinCities.com|date=2013-11-27|accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref>
===Communities=== After incidents during late 2013 in Brooklyn in which Jews were victims of knockout attacks, Jewish leaders, councilmembers, and organization representatives spoke against the attacks.<ref name="DNA"/><ref name="hamodia">{{cite web|last=Donn|first=Yochonon|url=http://hamodia.com/2013/11/25/black-leaders-uniting-condemn-knockouts|title=Black Leaders Uniting to Condemn Knockouts|publisher=Hamodia.com|accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref><ref name="Israel National News">{{cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/174339|title=NY Jewish Leader: Working to Stop "Knockout Game"|publisher=[[Israel National News]]|date=2013-11-22|accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref>
Leaders from the African-American community also made statements. New York City councilman [[Charles Barron]] stated that the root of the problem was a need for jobs to keep young people out of trouble; he also suggested additional funding for community patrols to act as [[lookout]]s.<ref name="lack of job">{{cite web|url=http://brooklyn.news12.com/news/community-leaders-in-east-new-york-blame-lack-of-jobs-for-knockout-game-violence-1.6507548|title=Community leaders in East New York blame lack of jobs for knockout game violence|publisher=Brooklyn.news12.com|date=2013-11-27|accessdate=2013-12-01}}</ref> Representative [[Hakeem Jeffries]] said at a Crown Heights Youth Collective conference that attacks based on race will not be tolerated and that the collective will do everything in its power to see that justice is done.<ref name="hamodia"/> Brooklyn's then-[[District Attorney]]-elect [[Kenneth P. Thompson]] called out the attacks, saying that "there is no status to be gained" for knocking out an unsuspecting victim and that such violence will not be tolerated. Brooklyn Borough President-elect [[Eric Adams (politician)|Eric Adams]] affirmed Thompson's statement, saying that, if you "play this game, ... you will lose".<ref name="hamodia"/>
Other notable New York City community members who have spoken against the attacks include Reverend [[Al Sharpton]]<ref name=sharpton>{{cite news|last1=Roberts|first1=Georgett|last2=Gartland|first2=Michael|url=https://nypost.com/2013/11/23/al-sharpton-condemns-knockout-attacks|title=Al Sharpton condemns 'knockout' attacks | New York Post|publisher=Nypost.com|date=2013-11-23|accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref> and [[Dov Hikind]].<ref name="hamodia2">{{cite web|last=Donn|first=Yochonon|url=http://hamodia.com/2013/11/19/jewish-black-leaders-meet-crown-heights-crime|title=Jewish, Black Leaders Meet Over Crown Heights Crime|publisher=Hamodia|date=2013-11-19|accessdate=2013-12-02}}</ref> [[Al Sharpton]], [[Russell Simmons]], [[Foundation for Ethnic Understanding]] founder Rabbi [[Marc Schneier]], former NYC mayor [[David Dinkins]] and former New Orleans mayor and current [[National Urban League]] president [[Marc Morial]] released a video in December 2013 saying "No to K.O."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theyeshivaworld.com/news/headlines-breaking-stories/205079/video-firmer-nyc-mayor-david-dinkins-releases-video-to-condemn-knockout-attacks.html|title=Video: Former NYC Mayor David Dinkins Releases Video To Condemn 'Knockout Attacks'|publisher=theyeshivaworld.com|date=2013-12-04|accessdate=2013-12-08}}</ref> Retired Brooklyn-born [[boxer]] [[Mike Tyson]] has also spoken against the attacks on ''[[The Piers Morgan Show]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://piersmorgan.blogs.cnn.com/2013/11/27/mike-tyson-on-knockout-game-theres-just-some-evil-people|title=Mike Tyson on "Knockout" game: "There's just some evil people"|publisher=The Piers Morgan Interview|first=Jason|last=Kurtz|date=2013-11-27|accessdate=2013-12-28}}</ref>
==Criticism of reporting== {{undue weight|section|date=November 2015}} The existence of a growing trend of knockout attacks has been questioned; claims about the prevalence of the phenomenon have been called an "urban myth" and a "type of panic" by some political analysts.<ref name=times/>
A June 2011 investigative report by John Tucker of the ''[[Riverfront Times]]'' following the death of Hoang Nguyen in 2011 saw many related attacks, all attributed to the "Knockout King" game. St. Louis Metropolitan Police Department Chief Daniel Isom stated that a year prior the police determined that the knockout game was played by a group of children who went around trying to knock random people unconscious. The police estimated the activity was not widespread and limited to five or nine teens. In Tucker's interviews with local teens, they believed the number to be much higher; one 18-year-old estimated 10-15% of his peers played the game. A St. Louis area barber said that in his youth the phenomenon was not called "Knockout King" but "One Hitter Quitter". [[Mike Males]] of the Center on Juvenile and Criminal Justice claimed that the media has been cherry-picking related attacks for sensationalism, asserting that "This knockout-game legend is a fake trend." Police at the time believed such attacks might have been under-reported by immigrant victims in communities where relations with law enforcement had been tense.<ref>{{cite web|author=John H. Tucker|url=http://www.riverfronttimes.com/2011-06-09/news/knockout-king-elex-murphy-hoang-nguyen-dutchtown-murder/full|title=Knockout King: Kids call it a game. Academics call it a bogus trend. Cops call it murder|publisher=Riverfront Times|date=2011-06-09|accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref>
An attack from 2012 in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] was tentatively linked to more recent attacks, although it was never identified as part of any "game".<ref name=cnn/> Police in [[Syracuse, New York]], reported that one assailant in a fatal attack admitted to its being "knockout", with a police sergeant noting that the assaults he was investigating were definitely "for a game" rather than being attempted murders or robberies.<ref name=times>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/23/nyregion/knockout-game-a-spreading-menace-or-a-myth.html?_r=1&|title=Police Unsure if Random Attacks Are Rising Threat or Urban Myth|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2013-11-23|first=Cara|last=Buckley|date=2013-11-22}}</ref>
On November 23, 2013, ''The New York Times'' reported that police officials in New York City were considering their position on the "game" and were wondering if they should advise the public, but had to contend with the uncertain existence of the game.<ref name=times/> Police in New York City questioned whether they were faced with a trend or a series of isolated incidents.<ref name=cnn>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/11/22/justice/knockout-game-teen-assaults|title=Police keep close eye on reports of disturbing 'knockout' game|publisher=CNN|date=2013-11-22|accessdate=2013-11-30}}</ref> Then-New York Police Commissioner [[Raymond Kelly]] refused to refer to the attacks in Brooklyn as the "knockout game" to avoid possible copycat attacks.<ref name=msnphilly>{{cite web|url=http://news.msn.com/crime-justice/knockout-game-a-crime-trend-or-random-violence|title='Knockout game': A crime trend or random violence?|publisher=News.msn.com|accessdate=2013-11-28}}</ref>
Several assaults associated with the knockout game do not follow any particular pattern; in several instances, a single assailant attempted a one-punch attack while in others multiple assailants participated in a gang attack. The "Knockout King" death of Nguyen in St. Louis was such a gang attack. A purported trend was identified in [[Lansing, Michigan]] called "point 'em out, knock 'em out" involved the use of a [[Taser]].<ref name=msnphilly/>
Many officials have outright refused to refer to the assaults as a "game", with Philadelphia Mayor [[Michael Nutter]] explicitly stating he did not want to give the idea any credibility while at a press conference after an attack at a Philadelphia pizzeria where the suspects never mentioned the game.<ref name=msnphilly/> In a [[CNN]] interview with [[Don Lemon]], Nutter stated he was not sure if the knockout game is real or not, adding he less concerned about the name but saying the incidents are of "great concern" and could spark copycat behavior. Nutter would not answer if the attacks were racially motivated and stated that Philadelphia has no confirmed "game" incidents.<ref>{{cite web|first=Simon|last=van Zuylen-Wood|url=http://www.phillymag.com/news/2013/12/04/mike-nutter-cnn-dont-know-knockout-game-real|title=Mike Nutter on CNN: I Don't Know If Knockout Game Is Real|publisher=Phillymag.com|date=2013-12-04|accessdate=2013-12-09}}</ref> Earlier, Philadelphia Police spokeswoman Tanya Little determined a November 11 attack as part of a knockout game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/2013-11-24/news/44391897_1_knockout-game-south-philadelphia-assault|title=Police: Recent assault was 'knockout game'|publisher=Articles.philly.com|date=2013-11-24|accessdate=2013-12-09}}</ref>
Jamelle Bouie of ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' was critical of the game's existence as a trend, comparing its existence to the "wilding" assault allegedly at hand in the [[Central Park jogger case]] and the often reported [[Headlight flashing#Urban legend|headlight flashing urban legend]]. While he did not deny that several people were attacked and one had died, he pointed out that the attacks were not really rare, noting the FBI had reported 127,577 unarmed assaults in 2012.<ref name=beast>{{cite web|last=Bouie|first=Jamelle|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/11/25/guess-what-the-knockout-game-is-america-s-latest-phony-panic.html|title=Guess What? The 'Knockout Game' Is America's Latest Phony Panic|publisher=''[[The Daily Beast]]''|date=2013-11-25|accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref>
When Singal approached several local news stations, a representative from an [[NBC]] affiliate responded saying that the footage had been taken from a shared pool of stock footage that other NBC stations in the area were given, and generally, if the footage is found to be inaccurate there would be a digital note concerning it. The note was absent in the case of the London video for reasons unknown. Singal's investigation led him to believe that people around the country are being told a story that has not been properly researched.<ref>{{cite web|last=Singal|first=Jesse|url=http://www.cjr.org/minority_reports/knockout_video_misuse.php?page=all|title='Knockout' reports illustrated with unrelated footage: Columbia Journalism Review|publisher=[[Columbia Journalism Review]]|date=2013-11-27|accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref>
[[Chris Hayes (journalist)|Chris Hayes]], host of [[MSNBC]]'s ''[[All In with Chris Hayes]]'', gave the knockout game his first annual "Over-Covered Stories of the Year" award, due to what he perceived as excessive coverage by Fox News.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wilstein|first=Matt|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/chris-hayes-blames-fox-news-for-2013s-most-over-covered-story|title=Chris Hayes Blames Fox News for 2013′s Most ‘Over-Covered’ Story|publisher=[[Mediaite]]|date=2013-12-24}}</ref>
Robin Abcarian for the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' criticized this reporting style by a conservative analyst, saying that blame was shifted onto the federal government. Abcarian noted that Barrett explicitly stated he was seeking a black victim, and postulated that he may have been acting on this "lazy narrative that black teens were randomly attacking white people". She criticized the statement by Rev. Sharpton and the conservative news sources who began supporting him after decades of opposition.<ref name=abcariancrazy>{{cite news|first=Robin|last=Abcarian|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-why-this-version-of-the-knockout-game-makes-conservatives-crazy-20131230,0,5557347,full.story#axzz2pRagcVrZ|title=Why this version of the 'knockout game' makes conservatives crazy|publisher=latimes.com|date=2013-12-30|accessdate=2014-01-04}}</ref>
Tommy Christopher, writing for [[Mediaite]], claimed [[James Rosen (journalist)|James Rosen]]'s report for [[Fox News]] on the attack was misleading, noting claims made by Rosen that it is the first such attack to be charged as a hate crime, when it was the first under federal statute. Christopher cited the arrest of Amrit Marajh in Brooklyn and the investigation of the alleged assault on Taj Patterson, a gay black man who claimed he was attacked by a group of Orthodox Jewish men, as proof of this.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/fox-airs-inaccurate-report-on-media-fueled-knockout-game-hate-crime-against-elderly-black-man|title=Fox Airs Misleading Report on 'Knockout Game' Hate Crime Against Elderly Black Man|publisher=Mediaite|date=2013-11-23|accessdate=2014-01-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/taj-patterson-gay-black-student-beaten-brooklyn-possible-knockout-game-attack-claims-orthodox-jews|title=Taj Patterson, Gay Black Student Beaten In Brooklyn In Possible Knockout Game Attack, Claims Orthodox Jews Assaulted Him|publisher=Ibtimes.com|date=2013-12-10|accessdate=2014-01-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/brooklyn/black-student-hasidic-men-attacked-williamsburg-article-1.1542946|title=Black fashion student says Hasidic men attacked him, shouted anti-gay slurs in Williamsburg|publisher=NY Daily News|date=2013-12-10|accessdate=2014-01-04|location=New York}}</ref>
Abcarian criticized the reporting of this attack as possibly being related to the knockout game trend, as the alleged attackers sought out Patterson because he was gay rather than because he is black. She also brought up a case of a fabrication of a "knockout"-style attack, after the victim and her boyfriend revealed she had lied that she was attacked at random by a stranger and instead he had struck her, noting that the ''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]'' did not report the initial attack as a "knockout game" attack.<ref>{{cite web|last=Byers|first=Christine|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/crime-and-courts/woman-made-up-knockout-game-story-after-boyfriend-hit-her/article_3d614541-f78d-51e8-95a9-98bcd8507e61.html|title=Woman made up 'knockout game' story after boyfriend hit her, St. Louis police say|publisher=Stltoday.com|date=2013-12-06|accessdate=2014-01-04}}</ref> Abcarian claimed that the 2011 attack by Dajour Washington on James Addlesburger was being used for sensationalism. The video of the assault was shown by [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]], which Addlesburger felt was being exploited and manipulated to fan racial hatred. Washington, who spent nine months in juvenile detention for the attack, appeared on ''[[Nightline]]'' in 2013 and claimed he had not attacked Addlesburger because he was white but rather because he was the only man present. Washington also claimed that at the time of the attack he had never heard of the "knockout game".<ref name=abcarianfaux>{{cite news|last=Abcarian|first=Robin|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-knockout-game-faux-media-trend-20131211,0,7338857,full.story|title=The 'knockout game' faux media trend has finally jumped the shark|publisher=latimes.com|date=2013-12-12|accessdate=2014-01-04}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox police officer |name = Malcolm Fewtrell |image = |image_size = |birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1909|9|28}} |death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2005|11|28|1909|9|28}} |badgenumber = |birth_place = [[Ryde]], Isle of Wight |death_place = |department = [[Buckinghamshire Constabulary]] |serviceyears = |rank = [[Chief Superintendent#United Kingdom and the Commonwealth|Chief Superintendent]]. |awards = |relations = |box_width = 260px }}
'''Ernest Malcolm Fewtrell''' (28 September 1909 – 28 November 2005) was a Detective [[Chief Superintendent]] in the [[Buckinghamshire Constabulary]] and head of [[Buckinghamshire]] [[Criminal Investigation Department|CID]]. He led the initial investigation into the [[Great train robbery (1963)|Great Train Robbery]] in 1963.<ref name=telegraph>{{cite news|title=Chief Superintendent Malcolm Frewtrell|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1505956/Chief-Superintendent-Malcolm-Frewtrell.html|publisher=telegraph.com.uk|accessdate=2 December 2013|location=London|date=21 December 2005}}</ref><ref name=dailymail>{{cite news|title=Raid that went off the rails|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/books/article-2267668/Raid-went-rails-THE-GREAT-TRAIN-ROBBERY-CRIME-OF-THE-CENTURY-BY-NICK-RUSSELL-PAVIER-AND-STEWART-RICHARDS.html|publisher=dailymail.com.uk|accessdate=2 December 2013|location=London|first=James|last=Walton|date=24 January 2013}}</ref><ref name=pressmon>{{cite web|title=MALCOLM FEWTRELL|url=http://www.pressmon.com/cgi-bin/press_view.cgi?id=977508|publisher=pressmon.com|accessdate=2 December 2013}}</ref><ref name=thetimes>{{cite web|title=Malcolm Fewtrell|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/opinion/obituaries/article2084858.ece|publisher=thetimes.co.uk|accessdate=2 December 2013}}</ref>
==Early life== Fewtrell was born in [[Ryde]], on the [[Isle of Wight]], where his father was a police officer. He attended [[Reading School]], then spent 6 months in [[New South Wales]], Australia working as a [[jackaroo (trainee)|jackaroo]] on [[sheep station]]s. He then returned to the UK and became a [[police cadet]] with the Buckinghamshire Constabulary in 1927. Three of his five brothers also joined the police. After serving a uniformed [[police constable]], he joined Buckinghamshire CID. He married Anne Thomas in 1934, who was a nurse in the hospital where he had his appendix removed.<ref>Alex May, 'Fewtrell, (Ernest) Malcolm (1909–2005)', Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, Jan 2009 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/96206 accessed 14 Feb 2014]</ref>
His [[reserved occupation]] as a police officer made him exempt from military service in the [[Second World War]]. He rose through the police ranks, becoming [[Detective Inspector]] at [[Chesham]] in 1950, and [[Detective Superintendent]] in 1954, and head of Buckinghamshire CID. He was involved in the [[A6 murder]] investigation when he was asked to find 10 redheaded men for an identity parade with [[James Hanratty]].
==Great Train Robbery== On 8 August 1963, Fewtrell was called out in the early morning to Bridgego Bridge, near [[Linslade]]. He was head of the [[Buckinghamshire]] [[Criminal Investigation Department|CID]] located at [[Aylesbury]], and within a year of his scheduled retirement.
The track-side signal lights had been tampered with to stop the Glasgow–London [[Travelling Post Office|mail train]]. The engine and the high-value carriage, containing money deposited at Scottish banks after the previous [[bank holiday]] weekend, had been decoupled from the other carriages, which were left a mile behind at Sears Crossing. The gang of robbers escaped with £2,600,000 of used banknotes. The train's driver, [[Jack Mills]], had been beaten over the head and never fully recovered.
Fewtrell arrived at the scene of the crime at 5am and gathered evidence before taking statements from the driver and postal workers at [[Cheddington railway station]]. He established that about 15 hooded men in boiler suits were involved. Fewtrell originally thought that the robbers could have escaped to London via the nearby [[M1 motorway|M1]], but one member of the gang had made the mistake of telling the postal staff not to move for half an hour after they left and this suggested to the police that their hide-out could not be more than {{convert|30|mi}} away. Having failed to find any forensic evidence at the crime scene, the police fanned out on a major search.
The resources of the Buckinghamshire police force were stretched, and Fewtrell advised the [[Chief Constable of Buckinghamshire]] to call in the [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] at [[Scotland Yard]]. Over the following days, Fewtrell worked closely with Detective Superintendent [[Gerald McArthur]] reviewing the clues in the local area, while Detective Chief Superintendent [[Tommy Butler]] and Detective Sergeant [[Jack Slipper]] investigated leads in London. The gang's hideout at Leatherslade Farm near [[Oakley, Buckinghamshire|Oakley]] was discovered a few days later. After the farm was found by local police, Fewtrell visited with two Metropolitan Police detectives, where they found food, drink, and items from the train, all covered with fingerprints. As Fewtrell later recalled, "the whole place is one big clue." Fewtrell also interviewed [[Brian Field]] who was a solicitor's clerk who helped the robbers buy their hideout and he obtained an admission of responsibility for a hotel bill paid for with some of the stolen money. Most of the gang were captured, with the first arrests on 15 August.
The trial of the gang members opened in Aylesbury in January 1964. The local court building was too small for the numbers of defendants, lawyers, witnesses and journalists in attendance, so the trial was held in the offices of Aylesbury District Council instead. Fewtrell was in charge of security of the venue and the accused, and the evidence (including £300,000 in cash that had been recovered).
Fewtrell's last day of service in the police was 16 April 1964, when he attended court for the sentencing. Six of the twelve defendants were sentenced to 30 years in prison – a total 307 years between then.
==Later life== With journalist [[Ronald Payne]], Fewtrell wrote two long articles in ''The Sunday Telegraph'' on 19 and 26 April 1964, and a book, ''The Train Robbers'' in 1964.
On leaving the police he worked at [[University of Portsmouth|Portsmouth Polytechnic]] as an accommodation officer. He retired a second time in 1974, to [[Swanage]] in Dorset where he administered the [[neighbourhood watch]].<ref name=telegraph />
He died at Poole Hospital, after a stroke. His wife predeceased him, and he was survived by a son and a daughter. His obituary in the ''Daily Telegraph'' noted a passing resemblance to [[John Thaw]] playing [[Inspector Morse]].
==Media portrayal== Malcolm Fewtrell is a character in ''A Copper's Tale'', the second part of a [[BBC]] television drama entitled ''[[The Great Train Robbery (TV series)|The Great Train Robbery]]'' that was broadcast in December 2013. The role was played by [[Richard Hope (actor)|Richard Hope]].<ref name=BBC>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/mediapacks/greattrainrobbery/ Great Train Robbery – at BBC Media Centre]. Retrieved 24 November 2013</ref>

{{Infobox website | name = Man Beef | logo = | url = ManBeef.com | type = Former hoax website | commercial = No | registration = None needed | owner = Chris Ellerby/Joseph Mallett | author = Chris Ellerby/Joseph Mallett | launch date = 2001-01-04 | current status = Inactive }} '''ManBeef.com''' was an elaborate [[hoax]] site beginning in January 2001, purporting to sell human meat, and offering tips and [[recipe]]s on preparing meals. Colorful pictures and illustrations adorned the site to further the appearance of legitimacy. Like [[Bonsai Kitten]], many individuals fell for the hoax and were disgusted. News of the site spread primarily by means of [[Chain e-mail|e-mail forwarding]], often in the form of petitions calling to stop the immorality.
To avoid exposing the hoax, ManBeef claimed they did not allow customers to purchase meat products from the site itself. "We do this, because we prefer to deal with our customers on a more personal basis," the disclaimer stated in part. The only products actually available to purchase were souvenir merchandise such as [[mousepad]]s, [[mug]]s and [[t-shirt]]s.
==Traffic== At its peak, the site received about 500,000 hits daily.<ref name=Hoaxipedia>{{cite web|title=Manbeef.com |url=http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/hoax/Hoaxipedia/Manbeef.com/ |year=2008 |work=Hoaxipedia |publisher=Alex Boese |accessdate=1 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090208160524/http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/hoax/Hoaxipedia/Manbeef.com/ |archivedate=8 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> It was causing so much controversy that the [[Food and Drug Administration (United States)|U.S. Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) launched an investigation, and found no wrongdoing because there was no evidence of human meat actually being sold.<ref name=Hoaxipedia/> In June 2001, the creators of the site, Chris Ellerby and Joseph Mallett, who used the combined [[pseudonym]] "Joseph Christopherson",<ref name=About>{{cite web |title=Yes, We Have No Manbeef |url=http://urbanlegends.about.com/library/weekly/aa072301a.htm |work=Urban Legends |publisher=About.com |accessdate=1 September 2009}}</ref> declared that the site was indeed a hoax,<ref>{{cite web |title=Where's the ManBeef? |url=http://www.snopes.com/inboxer/hoaxes/manbeef.asp |date=10 January 2009 |work=Snopes.com |publisher=Barbara and David P. Mikkelson |accessdate=1 September 2009}}</ref> and in July, issued a statement to ''[[The Columbian]]''<ref>{{cite web |title= Human Flesh For Sale For Cooking at Manbeef.com-Fiction! |url=http://www.truthorfiction.com/rumors/m/manbeef.htm |publisher= TruthOrFiction.com |accessdate=1 September 2009}}</ref> stating the purpose of the site was to "outrage the more sensitive viewers".<ref name=About/>
==Demise== In 2005, the registration for the ManBeef.com domain name expired and was quickly taken by a [[pornography]]-themed [[Cybersquatting|cybersquatter]]. {{as of|2014|June|18}}, the website was a parked domain for sale at >= $10,000.
==Copycat sites== KittyBeef.com and PuppyBeef.com (now defunct) were similar hoax sites that claimed to sell [[cat]] and [[dog]] meat.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.peta.org/blog/kitty-beef/ |title=Kitty Beef |publisher=[[PETA]] blog |date=25 July 2007 |accessdate=28 August 2014 |quote=We’ve been getting a ''lot'' of calls from people asking what we’re going to do about some new websites that are being passed around, called KittyBeef.com and PuppyBeef.com, which are purporting to sell prime cuts from kittens and puppies at discount prices. Well, the simple answer is … we’re not really going to do all that much about it at all. In fact, I kind of wish we’d thought of the idea ourselves.}}</ref> They used the ManBeef site as a template, though [[cat meat]] and [[dog meat]] are in fact readily consumed in parts of the world.
==See also== * [[Hufu]] * [[Soylent Green]]

{{unreferenced|date=December 2016}} A '''messabout''' is an event where a group of people get together to discuss and "mess about" in boats. The concept is not new but the name is. The term originated in April 1990 when Joe Tribulato organized the first such event with this name. This was the beginning of the Southern California Small Boat Messabout Society, SCSBMS. The term is derived from the children's book "[[The Wind in the Willows]]", by [[Kenneth Grahame]]. In the story, Mole and Rat are rowing up the river in Rat's boat. They are discussing [[nautical]] things and life in general when Rat is heard to utter,
Believe me, my young friend, there is nothing — absolutely nothing — half so much worth doing as simply messing about in boats. Simply messing... about in boats — or with boats. In or out of ’em, it doesn't matter. Nothing seems really to matter, that's the charm of it. Whether you get away, or whether you don't; whether you arrive at your destination or whether you reach somewhere else, or whether you never get anywhere at all, you're always busy, and you never do anything in particular; and when you've done it there's always something else to do, and you can do it if you like, but you'd much better not.
[[File:Shrike-port-beam.jpg|thumb|A 19'6" [[Phil Bolger]]-designed bald-headed knockabout schooner Shrike sailing to windward on port tack, near Kingston Ontario. The specific design is known as the "His and Her" or "Singlehanded" schooner.]]Messabouts are usually attended by a group of people who have taken up [[boat building]], [[boating]] and all things boat-related as their primary hobby. While many people have been at this hobby for quite some time, the advent of the [[Internet]] has allowed them to network on a level not seen before. They come from all over to get together for [[camaraderie]]. "Messabouts" is replaced in UK especially on canals by "banter" and the emphasis will be more on talk and [[camaraderie]] than actually doing anything constructive. ==External links== *[http://www.duckworksmagazine.com ''Duckworks''] magazine, with information on scheduled messabouts. *[http://www.tsca.net ''The Traditional Small Craft Association''], with 24 chapters around the USA hosting messabouts to celebrate the virtues of traditional rowing and sailing craft. [[Category:Boats]] [[Category:Social events]]

The '''Mieres uprising''' ({{lang-ca|Alçament de Mieres}}) was a peasant revolt which occurred on 22 September 1484 in the valley of [[Mieres, Girona|Mieres]] ([[Garrotxa]]). It was led by [[Pere Joan Sala]], and precipitated by the attempted seizure of the property of farmers that were not willing to accede to the ''[[droit du seigneur]]''. It was the beginning of the [[Second War of the Remences]] (''Peasants' War'').<ref name="Soldevila-1963">{{cite book |language=Catalan |last=Soldevila |first=Ferran |title=Història de Catalunya |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dWg-Tq2yqEEC&pg=PA000 |edition=2nd rev. & augm. |volume=2 |year=1963 |orig-year=1934 |publisher=Editorial Alpha |location=Barcelona |page=798 |oclc=632832415 |accessdate=6 July 2017 |quote= }}</ref>
The revolt came about in the environment following the [[Catalan Civil War]], and the king's 1481 approval of a constitution favouring the rights of the nobility over those of the [[remensa]]s.<ref>Bolòs, Jordi: ''Diccionari de la Catalunya medieval (ss. VI-XV)''. Edicions 62, Col·lecció El Cangur / Diccionaris, núm. 284. [[Barcelona]], [[abril]] del 2000. {{ISBN|84-297-4706-0}}, plana 173.</ref>
